positions.title: Founder
positions.description:
Founder of criminal justice reform group at Oberlin College.

"We, as the Prison Justice Project, believe the incarceration system is a counter productive way to create a healthier society. In its current state, the institution systematically dehumanizes individuals based on race, gender, sexual orientation, class, ability, political status, and religion. We are advocating a more humane approach to criminal justice through activism, coalition building, education, outreach, and solidarity. We recognize our unique position as student organizers and because of this, we will hold ourselves accountable to the communities with which we wish to engage. We understand that these issues are multifaceted and we seek to build alliances with other organizations seeking to dismantle systems of oppression."

As the leader of this project I co-taught a college course on the state of American Prisons to 12 students at Oberlin College.
I later secured over $10,000 in two months from grants and donations and managed those funds to both bring in speakers from across the country and finance other college events.
Along with a team of ten others, I launched 3 month speaker series, "Bars, Walls and Bodies" on the future of criminal justice reform.
In two months I had recruited over 200 students for future event planning and fundraising efforts and developed College-Prison Partnership with Grafton Prison in Ohio which is still in negotiation phase to launch a College curriculum in the prison as of June 2011.

given.text:
Francesca joined MongoDB at the same time I did, in November 2011. We were a scruffy open source startup with a few dozen employees, crammed into an office with warped floorboards above a nail salon. In the six years since, we have grown into a billion-dollar public company and the leading NoSQL vendor. Francesca's leadership has been crucial to our success: she has engaged the worldwide developer community, organized hundreds of events from small meetups to prestigious conferences, and developed MongoDB as a respected brand among software engineers. Her strategy is to inspire our engineering staff and our fans to be public advocates for MongoDB, to speak to the software engineering community with an authentic voice. This strategy paid off dramatically in 2017: the Stack Overflow Developer Survey found that "more developers wanted to work with MongoDB this year than any other database," beating the runner-up by a 2-to-1 margin.

Francesca and I worked closely for many years and it was always a pleasure to see her tackle a new problem. She enthusiastically attacks problems and ideas. She thinks outside of the box and provides ideal solutions to complex problems. Francesca helped me grow as an engineer and helped MongoDB grow by building a grassroots-community following. She found hundreds of small meetups, conferences, and events that needed attention and found a way to efficiently deliver resources to them. She even convinced people to start their own MongoDB meetups. I'd be happy to work with Francesca again!

I worked with Francesca for two years, initially in different departments and eventually as her manager (in Marketing). She did a tremendous job helping to build and support the fastest-growing, biggest community in Big Data. Her dedication to and passion for open source, generally, and for MongoDB's development community, specifically, was felt throughout the organization. She treated our open-source community like rock stars. By itself this would be nice: developers are the new market makers, and getting them on your side is a great way to build one's business. Francesca understands how to work with developers extraordinarily well, and has a habit of building strong relationships with developers that turn into great marketing programs, great content (blogs, white papers, etc.), and more. In turn, Francesca's work with MongoDB's developer community had a huge positive impact on our ability to make money. The more developers building on or around MongoDB; the more developers sharing positive stories about their use of MongoDB in public or in private conversations; the faster our business grew. Francesca was the heart of that community outreach. Francesca's title throughout that time is deceptive: ostensibly she's all about "community," which the industry translates as "developers." But "community" belies the breadth of the work Francesca does. She's an intuitive marketer, perhaps picked up from her understanding of developers, and is good at honing a message and figuring out the appropriate channels for expressing it. She has a sixth sense for what will win over customers/advocates for a brand, and what will bomb. Throughout it all she's thoughtful, fun and intelligent. I loved working with her and would jump at the chance to do so again. She's an A-player.

Francesca thinks big. She is not afraid to explore new ideas, and she takes initiative to develop new tools and systems that will benefit her team's work. For example, as a Development Fellow at the Taproot Foundation, one of Francesca's key responsibilities was to research funding prospects for the organization. When she noticed that most of Taproot's prospecting channels were exhausted, she proposed new strategies--especially those involving social media--to help her peers and managers explore funding opportunities with greater focus. In addition, Francesca's enthusiasm is contagious. She takes on projects with gusto, she is dedicated to growing as a professional, and she is quick to provide support when she is called upon. I enjoyed working with her tremendously.

received.text: I've worked with Jesse on a variety of projects at MongoDB in my 5+ years at the company. In that time, Jesse's leadership spanned beyond his role in engineering, but also to marketing and recruiting. He quickly established himself as a thought leader in the Python community,  and brings that responsibility to MongoDB. He is consistently the person I go to for thoughtful advice on how to better service the needs of our developer community and the company as a whole. When Jesse is involved in a project, I know that we will all be more thoughtful, innovative and and as a result working better together. I feel fortunate that I've got to learn and grow with someone like Jesse at MongoDB. I look forward to working with him in the future.

Sterio was a huge asset at our annual user conference, MongoDB World 2016. He was hired as a social media ambassador to encourage our audience to share their experience on social media and raise awareness of the event. To say he went above and beyond is an understatement. There I saw how he interacted with and inspired our 2,000+ guests. He came up with creative ways to distribute our exclusive swag and build an engaging atmosphere where social was part and parcel of the conference, leading to millions of mentions. In addition to cultivating a positive atmosphere for attendees, what stood out about Sterio was that he never forgot his goal at the event: to make it an engaging experience, at the conference itself and on social media. 

As a result of Sterio and the team's efforts, our hashtag #MDBW16 was trending on Twitter throughout the conference. Even though Sterio was part of our team only for the duration of Mongo World, he was as dedicated and enthusiastic as any of us. I'm excited to see what he does next in his career and look forward to recommending him and sharing stories of his work in the future.
